vissa av dessa r inte en "fallacy"
"slippery slope" till exempel r inte jmfrbart med ad hominem
ad hominem r en "true fallacy" eftersom sanning inte beror p vem som yttrar den
"slippery slope" r ju bara att frutse fljdeffekter och inkluderas bara p listan fr att kristna ofta frutser ljliga fljdeffekter (djursex kommer bli lagligt om homoktenskap blir lagligt osv.) Men "slippery slope" r inte en "logical fallacy" t.ex. r det inte ett logiskt misstag att varna mot hatisk retorik fr att det kan leda till fysiskt vld. Det r bara ett slags argument som ofta anvnds felaktigt, inte en "fallacy".
nr man inkluderar faktiska argument i en lista av logiska felsteg blir det ju bara en lista av urskter fr att tillta sig att avfrda allt en oliktnkande sger som man inte tycker om och s luras man att tro att man har ett robust logiskt ramverk som bakgrund till varfr hen har fel och jag har rtt

"super strictly"
they don't have a problem to deal with to begin with. the only refugees that even want to come to south korea come from north korea and the totalitarian north korean regime acts as their border enforcement agency for them.
Japan is like the US with respect to non-latin american immigrants- you simply can't get there as a refugee without active participation from the state which makes it really easy to control inflow without infringing on civil society. Where the US struggles to control population movement is where there is a land connection and japan has nothing like that

protectionism isn't always bad for efficiency and competitiveness though.
I mean the basic argument is if you're not part of the innovation and restructuring that competition necessitates (because of protectionist policy) you will fall behind which is true but on the other hand you don't want that innovation to include too much outsourcing or else you will lose competency within the nation
for example china now has engineering tolerances way above what they used to simply because so many companies have their factories there, but what happens to european (or french) tolerances if nationwide basically all manufacturing moves to china? of course the same as what happened to Chinese tolerances before manufacturing moved there - stagnation (or lack of progress)
so you can stagnate in both protectionism and free trade, you have to have more detail than simply protectionism bad - free trade good

grats but you can easily beat the germans as poland instead of joining them
you just get yourself 40 combat width (this is important) infantry divisions with 4 line artillery and support anti tank, artillery, engineers, recon, and hospital and if you have experience to spare (you should) you can do a similar division but mountaineers on the carpathian borders (approx 12 mt divisions should do it on carpathian). with this setup you can spearhead prussian ports from danzig with 4 or 5 inf divisions and the rest of the inf divisions on the german border just do a massive push with grand battleplan doctrine and you win ez.
because of polands national focuses you'll have effective manpower rivaling germany and you can just turn around and reck the soviets once the italians and germans capitulate (should be done before soviets declare). if japan joined already you just ignore them until soviets capitulate too else you just annex axis and then you take china last and you can now kill the allies ez
